title: Royal Scot and Tornado roll in to Severn Valley Railway
text:
Severn Valley Railway plan volunteer recruitment drive 
Flying Scot is also on show this weekend and lucky visitors can ride behind one of the world’s most iconic steam trains on Saturday and Sunday. 
She said: “The weekend went really well and it was incredibly busy. Both Flying Scot and Tornado are world-famous and have a big following. 
“People came from far and wide to see them and it was a great weekend. 
“This weekend is the last time people will be able to see Flying Scot on our line for a while so we’re expecting another big turnout.” 
People lined the route to snap the steam engine as it passed through Kidderminster station on the way to Bewdley. 
The globe-trotting Royal Scot was built in 1927 and was one of the fastest trains on the London Midland and Scottish Railway in that period. 
It appeared on behalf of Britain at the 1933 Century of Progress exhibition in Chicago before touring America and Canada. 
At one point it even crossed the Rocky Mountains. What do you think? Be the first to comment 
It was retired in 1962 and bought by Billy Butlin to display at his Skegness holiday camp for a number of years. 
The Royal Scot ran briefly again in the 1970s before spending the next 30 years as a static exhibit. 
Last month thousands of visitors flocked to the railway for the annual Autumn Gala. 
And there was a well-known guest with the Duke of Gloucester, the railway’s patron,visiting to unveil a special plaque marking the heritage line’s 50th anniversary.
